Problem:
Consider a closed curve C in the complex plane and a function f(z) which is holomorphic inside and on C, except for isolated singularities inside C. We examine the effect of applying the contour integral transformation \\( g(f) = \\frac{1}{2\\pi i} \\int_C f(z) dz \\) which computes the residues of the function at its singularities.

Will applying g(f) to a function f(z) with known singularities give the same result as directly summing the residues of the singularities inside C without transforming by g(f)?
Explanation: Applying g(f) as described computes the residues of f at its singularities, which by the residue theorem, is precisely the sum of the residues at those points. Hence, applying g(f) achieves the same result as directly summing the residues of the singularities inside C.

causal_map: Applying g(f) → Direct computation of residues; Applying g(f) → Sum of singularities inside C; Sum of singularities inside C → Direct computation of residues
